## The big picture: circulation and gas exchange
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 60%;">

* **Direct exchange between every cell and the environment is not possible in all animals**
    + special structures for exchange & transport needed

<br/>

* **Respiratory systems: exchange with the environment**

<br/>

* **Circulatory systems: transport between exchange sites and body**

<br/>

* **Internal transport and gas exchange functionally related**
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:685px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/circ_system.png">

## Molecule trading
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 58%;">

* **Small molecules can move between cells and their surroundings by *diffusion* **
    + concentration gradients = net movement

<br/>

* **Diffusion is only efficient over small distances** 
    + much slower over long distances
    
<br/>

* **Molecular trading in animals occurs for every cell!**
    + gain O~2~ and nutrients
    + release CO~2~ and waste products
    
<br/>
    
* **Simple body: most cells in contact with environment**
* **Not simple body requires circulatory system**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:645px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/worms.png">

## Animals with gastrovascular cavities
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: right; width: 64%;">

* **Many animals have lots of cells in contact with environment**
    + hydras, jellyfish, flatworms

<br/>

* **Central *gastrovascular cavity* functions to distribute substances**
    + opening at one end connects cavity to water
    + allows fluid to bath inner and outer tissues
    + diffusion distance kept short

<br/>

* **Gastrovascular cavity can be highly branched**
    + extends into tentacles of cnidarians
    + covers high surface area of flatworms

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:70px; WIDTH:275px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/gastro.jpg">

## Animals with circulatory systems
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Circulatory systems have 3 components**
1. *Heart*
2. Interconnecting *vessels*
3. Circulatory *fluid*

<br/>

* **Fluid transport, via vessels, connects cytoplasm of cells to organs for gas exchange **

<br/>

* **Mammals &rarr; O~2~ diffuses over 2 cell layers in lungs to reach blood**
    + system then transports O~2~ rich blood to body 

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:625px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/basic.jpg">

## Vertebrate Circulatory systems
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Cardiovascular system: blood &rarr; heart &rarr; vessels**
    + length of vessels can be staggering

<br/>

* **3 main types of vessels**
1. Arteries: carry blood from heart to organs
2. Veins: carry blood back to heart
3. Capillaries: microscopic vessels with pores that infiltrate tissues

<br/>

* **Hearts of vertebrates have 2+ muscular chambers**
    + *atria* are chambers that receive blood
    + *ventricles* pump blood out
    
<br/>

* **Number of chambers related to form and function via natural selection**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:425px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/circsystem.jpg">

## Evolutionary variation: 3 chambered heart
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:75px; WIDTH:300px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/3chamber.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 64%;">

* **Amphibians and reptile hearts have 1 ventricle**
    + still use double circulation

<br/>

* **Do not always fill their lungs**
    + pass long periods without gas exchange
    + or use another tissue (skin)
    
<br/>
 
* **Example: frogs use skin when underwater**
* **Example: crocodiles shunt blood from lungs when underwater**

</div>

## Mammalian Circulation (2 circuits)
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 48%;">

* **Right ventricle pumps blood to the lungs via arteries**

<br/>

* **Blood flows through capillaries into lungs and loads O~2~ and unloads CO~2~**

<br/>

* **O~2~ rich blood returns from lungs via veins to the left atrium**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:425px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/mammal1.jpg">

## Mammalian Circulation (2 circuits)
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 52%;">

<br/>   

* **Blood flows to left ventricle and pumped to tissues via arteries into capillaries**
    + First branches supply the heart muscle
    + Further branches lead to organs and hind limbs

<br/>   

* **O~2~ diffuses from blood to tissues, and CO~2~ diffuses from tissues to blood**

<br/>   

* **Capillaries rejoin conveying blood to veins**
    + O~2~ poor blood from the head, neck, and forelimbs is emptied into right atrium

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:425px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/mammal1.jpg">

## Mammalian heart 
<hr>
<br/> 
<br/> 
<br/> 

<div style="float: right; width: 55%;">

* **Atria have thin walls and serve to collect blood returning to the heart**

<br/> 

* **Ventricles have thicker walls and contract much more forcefully**

<br/>   

* **The heart contracts and relaxes in a rhythmic cycle called the cardiac cycle**
    + 4 valves prevent back flow of blood in the heart

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:50px; WIDTH:450px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/mammal2.jpg">

## Blood flow
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 57%;">

* **Physical laws govern movement of fluids through pipes**
    + affect blood flow and pressure
    
<br/> 

* **Blood flows from areas of higher pressure to low**
    + resistance to flow in narrow diameters capillaries dissipates pressure

<br/>

* **Blood flow is slowest in the capillaries**
    + over large cross-sectional area
    + necessary for gas exchange

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:690px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/flow.jpeg">

## Gas exchange over respiratory surfaces
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Gas exchange = uptake of O~2~ from environment and release of CO~2~**
    + O~2~ is abundant in the air (21%)
    + fairly easily to 'breath'
    
<br/>
 
* **Water is more demanding for gas exchange**
    + dissolved O~2~ is variable but always less than air
    
<br/>
 
* **Efficient surfaces for gas exchange have evolved**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:625px; WIDTH:450px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/gasexchange.jpg">
    
## Respiratory Surfaces
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 49%;">

* **Differs across animal phylogeny**
    + sponges, cnidaria, flatworm &rarr; cells directly
    + earthworms, amphibians &rarr; skin
    
<br/>

* **Other animals lack enough surface area**
    + to much volume to supply with O~2~

<br/>

* **Respiratory organs evolve**
    + Gills &rarr; aquatic animals
    + Trachea &rarr; insects
    + lungs &rarr; reptiles and mammals

</div>

## Coordination of circulation and gas exchange
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 53%;">

* **Most animals need to exchange large amounts of O~2~ and CO~2~**
    + to meet metabolic needs

<br/>

* **During inhalation, fresh air fills in lung**
    + air mixture has more O~2~ than blood
    + blood has less CO~2~ than mixture
    + diffusion occurs

<br/>
    
* **Blood is then pumped through circuit**
    + O~2~ carried in pigments (metal bound to protein)
    + gradients of O~2~ and CO~2~ drive diffusion in body

</div>
